title: How to Make American Ginseng Tea

steps.headline: Place 1 tablespoon of finely chopped ginseng root into a mug.
steps.description: If you have a tea ball, you can put the root into that first. This way, you won't have to strain it out later. You can slice the fresh ginseng root using a sharp knife or a vegetable peeler.

steps.headline: Boil some water in a kettle.
steps.description: Fill your kettle with water, then let it come to a boil. It is best if you use purified water for this. Because water evaporates as it cooks, boil more water than you think you might need.

steps.headline: Let the water cool for 2 minutes.
steps.description: Once the water has come to a boil, take it off of the heat, and let it cool for 2 minutes. High levels of heat can destroy the beneficial properties of many herbs, including ginseng.

steps.headline: Pour 1 cup (240 milliliters) of the boiled water into the cup.
steps.description: Measure out the water first, then pour it straight into the cup with the ginseng in it.

steps.headline: Let the tea steep for 5 to 10 minutes.
steps.description: Some people like to place a saucer over the mug so that the tea doesn't cool down too much. The longer you steep the tea, the stronger it will be.

steps.headline: Strain the tea.
steps.description: If you used a tea ball, simply pull the tea ball out and discard the root. If you did not use a tea ball, pour the tea through a fine mesh strainer into another mug.

steps.headline: Drink the tea.
steps.description: It tastes best while it is still warm, but you can drink it cold too. If you are using this tea for medicinal purposes, you can take it 1 to 3 times daily for 3 to 4 weeks.

steps.headline: Fill a saucepan with water.
steps.description: You will need 1 cup (240 milliliters) of water for each serving of tea that you will be making. This is a great option if you need to make several servings of tea at one time.

steps.headline: Add the ginseng.
steps.description: You will need 1 tablespoon of dried ginseng root for each serving of tea.

steps.headline: Heat the water over low heat.
steps.description: Do not let it come to a boil. Boiling water can destroy the beneficial properties of ginseng.

steps.headline: Allow the ginseng to steep for up to 20 minutes.
steps.description: The longer you steep it, the stronger the tea will be. As the tea steeps, you can cover the pot with a lid; this way, the tea won't cool off too past.

steps.headline: Pour the tea through a fine, mesh strainer into a mug.
steps.description: Discard the root that is caught in the strainer.

steps.headline: Serve the tea.
steps.description: It tastes best while it is hot, but you can also drink it cold as well. If you want to, you can enhance its flavor with some lemon or honey.
